--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> You could just evaluate it against all 19,683
> possible board 
> positions, either as fitness, or just for testing. 
> The score
> is how many of the 19,683 moves are the same as that
> proposed by 
> BEST. (note that many of these are actually
> irrelevant since
> they already represent winning positions, so ignore
> those)

Yes, and symmetries can also be ignored.  This makes
sense.  It wouldn't be that difficult to sit down and
figure out all the possible legal moves for all
possible legal board states, excluding symmetry, and
determine what the best moves are for each.

--- Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@...> wrote:
> Mainly this was for consistency of evaluation. If a
> network recieved a
> score of 90% once, it should score 90% again on the
> next trial. I forget
> exactly why this was important (something to do with
> the data collection).

I understand that evaluation against a random opponent
is noisy, since there is of course a random element. 
This can be normalized by playing more games...which
then takes more computer resources, which you say you
were trying to conserve.

> "Solves" is used very loosely here. It solves
> tic-tac-toe in the sense
> that it cannot get much better playing against the
> strict opponent. 

Perhaps I'm being nitpicky here, but it would probably
have been more accurate to say that the networks
learned how to block threats, or how to tie, or how
not to lose.  Presumably your networks performed very
poorly against a random opponent (this has been my
experience in evolving directly against BEST).

> It depends on what your goal is. Mine was to
> demonstrate that Modular NEAT
> actually evolved things. 

Since evolution is essentially defined as a change in
gene frequencies in a population over time, I don't
think you'd even really need a fitness function to
simply evolve a population.

Somebody correct me if I'm wrong, but evolution would
occur even in a randomly-selected, randomly-mated
population due to simple genetic drift, which would be
even more pronounced in smaller populations.

I would think the goal of using a neuroevolutionary
technique such as NEAT would be to optimize the
performance of a particular entity in a particular
domain.

That is, evolution per se is not inherently
directional, but when we apply genetic algorithms, we
are trying to be directional, to solve a particular
problem.

Again, forgive me if I'm being pedantic and overly
literal, but there's enough conceptual and linguistic
fuzziness that I've noticed in the literature, and I
try to keep things clear in my head.

> Truly solving tic-tac-toe I
> think would require
> always tying the perfect player (in all of the
> perfect game trees), and
> always playing to win against non-perfect players.

Yeah, I agree.  What I'll probably do is use the
Angeline/Pollack method of benchmarking players, and
if manage to evolve individuals that always tie BEST
and nearly always win against RAND, I'll analyze their
move behavior my explicitly comparing its behavior to
BEST with every board configuration.

I've already also done a bit of planning for the next
domain we'd like to tackle, which is Gomoku
(five-in-a-row on a 15x15 board).  It's a high
input/output domain, with 225 possible moves on the
first turn and a very large branching factor, so
explicitly determining optimal moves as in Tic-Tac-Toe
isn't going to be feasible, I don't think.  

So I plan on evaluating our evolved Gomoku players
against hard-coded players or available freeware
players.  And there's a similar problem with Go, which
is our goal beyond Gomoku.  The strength of an evolved
player is probably going to have to be evaluated based
on its performance against either other available AIs
or, as Fogel did which Checkers, against humans.

Derek
